frontmatter.title: The algebra of programming

mainmatter.p: Relational calculus is notoriously difficult to work with for equational reasoning about programs in the style of the algebra of programming. It seems embedding relations in a topos as we have done here is a good idea to simplify this. However, we haven't tackled two fundamental operations on relations/span in this post:

ul.li: This first one is composition of relations/spans, which seems definable using the STC connectives.

The second one is taking the converse of relations/spans, which flips the left leg and right leg of a relation/span. This is an involutive functor on \mathbf{Sp} but it is not a strong functor, so it cannot be directly internalised as a functor inside the language of \mathbf{Sp}. Instead, we need to use some form of modal type theory to handle it.
